results.title: Dark lullabies
results.creator_credit: Abbey Jack Neidik, Bonnie Sherr Klein, Edward Le Lorrain, Irene Angelico, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: They are the children of survivors and of perpetrators of the Holocaust. Polarised as their heritage is, many of this generation share a legacy of silence. Canadian filmmaker Irene Angelico, herself a child of concentration camp survivors, undertakes a deeply personal journey; she asks what happened and why? This powerful documentary is structured around the filmmaker’s quest. Having grown up in the shadow of the Holocaust, she searches for comprehension through interviews with survivors and their children in Montreal and in Israel. Despite her own reluctance, her journey inevitably takes her to Germany. Rare interviews show a range of voices among her German contemporaries. Some are as compelled as she to pierce the silence, while others retreat into prejudice and denial. The film offers no easy answers. (Awards: Mannheim, New York, Tokyo)

results.title: Dark habits = entre tinieblas
results.creator_credit: Pedro Almodovar, Luis Calvo, Tesauro S A and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Prepare to meet some nuns like you’ve never met before. Junkie nightclub singer Yolanda Bell (Christina S Pascual), takes refuge with the religious order ‘the humble redeemers’, after her boyfriend overdoses on heroin and Yolanda’s on the run from the police. ‘The humble redeemers’ are a good hearted group, trying to save girls from leading a wild life. They do however have a dark side to their operations; dealing drugs, dabbling in pornography and active chain smoking admirers of Cecil Barton. Together they are planning a party to celebrate Mother Superior’s name day; it will be a party to end all parties. Described as an evil twin of films such as ‘Sister act’ and ‘The Sound of music’, this film is Almodovar at his devilish and controversial best. Cast includes Julieta Serrano, Julia Marisa Paredes and Mary Carrillo. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Oops those Hollywood bloopers
results.brief_description: A collection of bloopers and outtakes from an enormous selection of Hollywood classic productions spanning from the 1930’s right through to the 1980’s. Includes Ronald Reagan ‘Pants Down’, Errol Flynn ‘Mobbed in the Men’s Bath Tub’, Humphrey Bogart, Cary Grant, James Stewart, Bette Davis, Joan Crawford, Sammy Davis Jr., Tony Randall, Tiny Tim, Glenn Campbell (who’s overwhelmed by a black male dancer), Don Adams, Don Knotts, Anita Bryant, Christopher Lee, Dick Foran, Ben Gazzara, Marilyn Monroe, Debbie Reynolds, Boris Karloff plus many many more. This compilation also includes footage of the Beatles, Elvis, Diana Ross, Hitler doing a jig and the inclusion of short animation ‘Bambi meets Godzilla’ by Marv Newland. Please note: The use of rare film sources presents moments of variable picture and sound quality.

results.title: Oondamooroo: a profile of Ernie Dingo
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Don Featherstone Productions and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: The Aboriginal actor Ernie Dingo talks about his career, his origins, influences on his life and his feelings about his aboriginality. Features excerpts from his work on stage and screen, interviews with friends, mentors, family and wife and shows him at work teaching Aboriginal children to develop self-respect and white children to understand Aboriginal culture and history. An engaging look at an impressive and likeable personality.

results.title: Only 3000 BC kids remember
results.brief_description: Tiktok can be educational - but not in the way you might think. Information spreads not just through researched videos, but also levity, memes, and irreverent, lo-fi video content that entertain and provoke curiosity. Questions like ‘What is a phrase that someone born after 2000 wouldn’t understand’ usually garner stitched video responses from people enthusiastically reminiscing about ‘the good old days.’ Here instead, linguist Arum Natzorkhang pokes fun at the trend by responding in Proto-Indo-European, a reconstructed language which is hypothesised to be the common ancestor to all Indo-European languages.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Tiktok can be educational - but not in the way you might think. results.title: Only you
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Charles Mulvehill, Robert N. Fried, Gary Woods, Tri-Star Pictures, Yorktown Productions Ltd and Fried Woods Films
results.brief_description: This very romantic comedy is all about a girl named Faith (Marisa Tomei) who searches for her “soul mate” named Damon Bradley. She was advised of this name by the Ouija board and a gypsy fortune teller. A week before her wedding, “Damon” phones to say he is unable to attend. Faith believes she must leave her fiancee, travel to Italy, and find her date with destiny”. During her search, the wrong man (Robert Downy Jnr) falls madly in love with her. What is she to do? With breathless scenery and brilliant performances, it’s irresistible entertainment that everyone will enjoy. Cast also includes Billy Zane and Fisher Stevens.

results.title: Dark city [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alex Proyas, Andrew Mason and Dark City Productions
results.brief_description: Emanating from the same Fox studios as ‘The Matrix’, Alex Proyas’ ‘Dark City’ has the same impressive array of special effects and a rather enigmatic plot. The film begins with an amnesiac John Murdoch (Rufus Sewell) awakening in a bathtub, with no recollection of why he’s there and a tiny bloodspot on his forehead. Other people around him seem to know more about John’s memory than he does, including his estranged wife Emma (Jennifer Connelly), mad genius Dr Schreber (Kiefer Sutherland) and sympathetic policeman Frank Bumstead (William Hurt). John’s investigation into regaining his memory is set against a bleak film noir inspired background where the sun never rises, as well as a murder investigation into a series of deaths involving prostitutes (of which Murdoch is a suspect) and a former policeman (Colin Friels) who seems to have gone mad investigating the case. Both John’s investigation into his past and the police investigation into the murders are intricately involved with The Strangers - a band of gothic looking people who have a collective memory and have the ability to alter the physical world via a process called Turning - a capability that John possesses. The Strangers are driven by the need to replicate humans and ensure The Strangers survival, begging the question, what is it that makes us human? Cast also includes Richard O’Brien, Ian Richardson, Mitchell Butel, Frank Gallacher and Melissa George.

results.title: Dark angel
results.creator_credit: Sidney A. Franklin, Samuel Goldwyn and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of a World War I ravaged England, this superbly acted romantic drama is a true classic. Merle Oberon is a revelation as a reformed vamp torn between two men - Herbert Marshall and Frederic March, the latter having returned from the war blinded. The script was adapted by Lillian Hellman from the play by Guy Bolton (a.k.a R. B. Trevelyan).

results.title: Oneiro: in the shadow of Isadora [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Silvianna Goldsmith and Montclair State College
results.brief_description: Dance poem in three sections performed by Lori Belilove based on Belilove’s own choreography and improvisation as inspired by Isadora Duncan. Using special effects and computerized image processing, the dance sequences are superimposed onto images of ancient Greek temples, paintings, sculptures, and the Aegean Isles.

results.title: Onegin [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Martha Fiennes, Simon Bosanquet, Ileen Maisel, Onegin Productions and Baby Productions
results.brief_description: Jaded aristocrat, Evgeny Onegin (Ralph Fiennes), gladly abandons the decadent opulence of St. Petersburg’s high society after unexpectedly inheriting his uncle’s country estate. Despite feeling out of place in such a provincial setting, he manages to form an uneasy friendship with Vladimir Lensky (Toby Stevens), who introduces him to the sister of his fiance, Tatyana Larina (Liv Tyler). Tatyana becomes enamoured with Onegin and, caught up in the frenzy of first love, writes him a passionate letter expressing her feelings. However, she is devastated when Onegin cruelly rejects her and turns his attention to her sister, an action which eventually results in a duel with the enraged Lensky. Returning to St. Petersburg once again, Onegin spirals downward into a deep depression, obsessed with what might have been in this exquisitely filmed version of Alexander Pushkin’s famous novel, “Eugene Onegin”.
